message.content:
EXHAUSTIVE RESEARCH: Find ANY way to directly edit/cut/split/razor clips on the Premiere Pro timeline using UXP.

Search for:
1. Every method on SequenceEditor class - can any create cuts/splits?
2. TrackItem manipulation methods - setInPoint, setOutPoint, any split functions?
3. Hidden or undocumented UXP APIs for timeline editing
4. GitHub issues/discussions about timeline editing in UXP
5. Adobe forum posts about cutting clips in UXP
6. Any workarounds developers have found
7. SequenceEditor.createInsertProjectItemAction - can this simulate a cut?
8. Can you duplicate a clip and adjust in/out points to simulate a split?
9. Any beta/experimental APIs mentioned in documentation
10. TypeScript definitions that might reveal hidden methods

Be extremely thorough. Check every forum post, GitHub issue, and documentation page. We need to find if there's ANY way to cut/split clips in UXP.

This is research only - provide all findings with sources.

Based on my search, here's what I found about the Premiere Pro UXP SequenceEditor class API documentation:

## Premiere Pro UXP SequenceEditor Class

The SequenceEditor class allows you to get a Sequence Editor reference for editing the sequence timeline and get local directory path to Adobe mogrt files.

The official documentation for the SequenceEditor class is available at:
- **Direct link**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/sequenceeditor/

### Key Context

The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6.(no content)The documentation has been refreshed for the v25.6 release and covers the available core UXP and Premiere API surfaces needed to help you build your panels.(no content)The SequenceEditor APIs were announced as part of an update that also included ClipProjectItem API (which allows for attach proxy or high resolution footage or replace footage with attachProxy() and changeMediaPath()) and EncoderManager API (with getExportFileExtension()).

### Related Resources

1. **Main UXP API Documentation**: The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.

2. **Sequence Class** (related): The Sequence class includes methods to clear TrackItem Selection and create an action to clone a given sequence.

3. **Sample Code**: The Sample SDK provides practical examples of how to interact with the Premiere API using UXP. Available at: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples

4. You can now see and use TypeScript definitions for Premiere Pro's UXP APIs in Visual Studio Code.

### API Behavior

In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

For the complete list of SequenceEditor methods and detailed API documentation, I recommend visiting the official Adobe developer documentation page directly at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/sequenceeditor/.

Here are the search results from the Adobe Community forums for your query about Premiere Pro UXP and cutting/splitting clips on the timeline:

## Key Findings:

### UXP API and Razor Tool
"There is not yet any UXP API that mimics the razor tool. In PPro, all markers and metadata associated with trackItems, are actually attached to the backing projectItem; it's not possible to have different markers and metadata for each trackItem."(no content)Placing trackItems in a sequence is possible with UXP (same for CEP+ExtendScript). Exporting .srt files is also possible using an output preset (.epr file) that specifies the desired settings, and this works the same for both CEP+ExtendScript and UXP.

### Related UXP Discussion
A user asked about making a Premiere Pro UXP panel to automate cuts on the timeline, using workflow markers like _RecStart, _ShotMark1, and _ShotMark2 to mark sections.

### Traditional Razor Tool Usage
For non-UXP editing, the community discussions cover:

- The "Add Edit" command with the default shortcut CTRL+K/CMD+K is the keyboard method to split clips at the playhead position.

- Hold and press the Shift key when clicking with the razor tool to cut all clips regardless of targeting. Targeting tracks comes into play when using keyboard shortcuts like Ctrl+K.

- To undo a razor cut, you can right-click on the cut in the timeline and choose "Join Through Edits" from the dropdown menu.

- To have the razor tool cut linked audio and video together, toggle the "Linked Selection" button in the upper left corner of the timeline.

The bottom line is that there is not yet any UXP API that mimics the razor tool, so if you need to programmatically cut clips in Premiere Pro through a plugin, you may need to explore workarounds or wait for Adobe to add this functionality to the UXP API.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP TrackItem split/cut/razor API methods:

## Key Finding: No UXP API for Razor/Split Functionality

"There is not yet any UXP API that mimics the razor tool." This was confirmed in an Adobe community discussion from October 2025.

## Current TrackItem API Capabilities

The UXP API does provide some TrackItem functionality, but not splitting:

The API includes methods like `isDisabled()` which returns true if trackitem is muted/disabled, `createSetDisabledAction(disabled: boolean)` which returns an action that enables/disables the trackItem, `createSetNameAction(inName: string)` which returns an action that renames the trackItem, `getMediaType()`, `getTrackIndex()`, and `getProjectItem()`.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin shows how to clone and remove track items, but this doesn't include splitting clips.

## Razor Tool Events (Not Methods)

The API does include event constants related to the razor tool, such as `EVENT_SNAP_RAZOR_TO_PLAYHEAD` which occurs when the razor tool hovers over the playhead and snaps into position for a cut, and `EVENT_SNAP_RAZOR_TO_MARKER` which occurs when the razor tool hovers over markers and snaps into position for a cut. However, these are events for listening to user actions, not methods to programmatically perform cuts.

## TrackItem Properties Available

The TrackItem object has properties like `duration` (Time object, read-only), `end` for the visible end time of the trackItem in the sequence, and these properties may differ from the trackItem's out point, which is relative to the source (Time object, read/write).

## Alternative: ExtendScript (Legacy)

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.(no content)Placing trackItems in a sequence is possible with no problem, and this is the same for CEP+ExtendScript and UXP.

## Summary

Currently, there is **no programmatic way** to split/cut clips using the UXP API in Premiere Pro. While you can manipulate existing track items (enable/disable, rename, get properties, clone, remove), the razor/split functionality has not yet been exposed through the API. Developers looking for this functionality would need to wait for future API updates or explore workarounds involving creating new track items with different in/out points rather than splitting existing ones.

Here are the search results for "Adobe Premiere Pro UXP timeline editing cut clips GitHub issues":

## Summary of Findings

### UXP Timeline Editing Status

UXP scripting in Premiere Pro is experimental and limited. Some features (like timeline and sequence editing) may not be available yet.(no content)For full automation, use the CEP (legacy) panel.

### GitHub Projects Related to Premiere Pro UXP

1. **[AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples)** - The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available here: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.(no content)Premiere Pro BETA build, available through Creative Cloud Desktop. UXP Developer Tool, also available for download through Creative Cloud Desktop.

2. **[cameron-astor/jumpcut](https://github.com/cameron-astor/jumpcut)** - An open-source jump cut plugin for Adobe Premiere Pro.(no content)Adobe is working on phasing out CEP extensions in favor of UXP extensions. This is a CEP plugin, and so will eventually need to be ported to UXP. As of December, 2023, Premiere does not yet support UXP.

3. **[hetpatel-11/Adobe_Premiere_Pro_MCP](https://github.com/hetpatel-11/Adobe_Premiere_Pro_MCP)** - Notes that add_text_overlay — Text overlays (legacy titles) are deprecated/broken in modern Premiere Pro scripting. Adobe has removed or deprecated these scripting APIs. Only the features above are reliably scriptable.

### API Limitations for Clip/Track Editing

According to recent Adobe community discussions:

There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks. Premiere Pro no longer includes a keyboard mappable command like Move Clip Up/Down Between Tracks, meaning even UI automation...(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin, the right starting point for any future integrations, shows how to clone and remove track items.

### Official Documentation

The Premiere UXP API provides access to sequences, tracks, clips, markers, project items, and application settings.(no content)No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled. Any such changes will be reconsidered, once Premiere Pro moves to UXP-based extensibility.

### Community Questions

Users are working on Premiere Pro UXP panels to automate cuts on the timeline, including workflows that use clip markers for marking takes and sections to keep.

If you're looking for specific GitHub issues related to UXP timeline editing features, the main repositories to check would be [AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro) and the Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums at https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105.

# Timeline Editing API Request Summary

## Requested Functionality

The user seeks programmatic control to move clips between video tracks in Adobe Premiere Pro while preserving timing. Specifically, they want the ability to consolidate multi-track sequences into single tracks—functionality previously available through the `moveToTrack()` method in the QE API.

## Current Limitations

The request documents that:

- "There is **no current API method** (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks"
- The `moveToTrack()` function exists in QE but appears non-functional, returning parameter errors
- No keyboard-mappable command exists for track movement in current builds (2023-2025)

## Adobe's Response

An Adobe Employee (Bruce Bullis) stated: "Not sure why or how you're running into trouble with moveToTrack(); there have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned."

Adobe recommends using the **UXP 'premiere_api' example plugin** instead, which demonstrates how to clone and remove track items—suggesting a workaround rather than native track movement.

## Future Plans

Adobe provides no documented roadmap for exposing timeline editing in UXP or future APIs. The response indicates QE remains unsupported and recommends transitioning to UXP, but timeline manipulation remains unavailable.

content.content:
# Technical Analysis: Timeline Cutting in Premiere Pro UXP

## Problem Statement
The user seeks to automate video cuts using UXP by reading clip markers and removing sections between marked points. Specifically, they want to identify `_ShotMark1` and `_ShotMark2` markers, then delete content between them.

## Technical Findings

**API Limitations Identified:**
The Adobe employee response reveals a critical constraint: "PPro has no concept of 'clip-instance markers'; there are only sequence markers, or source markers."

This directly contradicts the user's approach. The UXP framework only supports:
- **Sequence markers** (applied to the timeline itself)
- **Source markers** (embedded in media files)

There are no dedicated APIs for reading markers attached to individual clips on the timeline.

## Workarounds Suggested

The community response doesn't provide explicit alternative solutions, only clarification that the requested feature architecture doesn't exist in Premiere Pro's object model.

**Implied approaches:**
1. Use sequence-level markers instead of clip-instance markers
2. Investigate whether source markers in linked media could substitute for the desired workflow

## API Methods Referenced

No specific UXP API methods are mentioned in the discussion. The response focuses on what's **not available** rather than what is.

## Conclusion

No hidden alternatives or established workarounds are documented. The user would need to redesign their marker strategy to align with Premiere Pro's actual marker hierarchy, or request feature enhancement from Adobe.

content.content:
# UXP Razor Tool Discussion Summary

## Main Question
A developer asked about implementing razor tool functionality in a Premiere Pro UXP plugin, specifically wanting to programmatically create cut sections, add markers, place clips in sequences, export SRT files, and extract video metadata.

## Adobe's Response
An Adobe employee (bbb_999) provided these key points:

**Current Limitations:**
- "There is not yet any UXP API that mimics the razor tool"
- Markers and metadata attach to projectItems, not individual trackItems
- Different markers per trackItem aren't currently supported

**What IS Possible:**
- Placing trackItems in sequences works without issue
- SRT export is achievable using output presets (.epr files)
- Video metadata extraction (width/height, XMP data) is accessible

**No Workarounds Mentioned**
The response offers no alternative methods or hidden APIs for razor functionality. The developer would need to either wait for future UXP expansion or fall back to CEP/ExtendScript if razor tool mimicry is essential.

**Future APIs:**
Adobe made no specific commitments about when razor tool APIs might arrive—only acknowledging the feature doesn't currently exist.

Based on the search results, I found information about the TrackItem methods in the Adobe UXP Premiere Pro types.d.ts file. Here's what I found:

## TrackItem Methods from AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro types.d.ts

The TrackItem interface includes the following methods:

- **isDisabled()**: `Promise<boolean>` - Returns true if trackitem is muted/disabled
- **createSetDisabledAction(disabled: boolean)**: `Action` - Returns an action that enables/disables the trackItem
- **createSetNameAction(inName: string)**: `Action` - Returns an action that renames the trackItem
- **getMediaType()**: `Promise<Guid>` - Returns UUID representing the underlying media type of this track item
- **getTrackIndex()**: `Promise<number>` - Index representing the track index of the track this track item belongs to
- **getProjectItem()**: `Promise<ProjectItem>` - Returns the project item for this track item(no content)Additional component-related methods include:
- **getComponentChain()**: `Promise<AudioComponentChain>` - Returns AudioComponentChain
- **createInsertComponentAction(component: Component | AudioFilterComponent, componentInsertionIndex: number)**: `Action` - Creates and returns an insert component action
- **createAppendComponentAction(component: Component | AudioFilterComponent)**: `Action` - Creates and returns an append component action

The source file is located at: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro/blob/main/src/pages/ppro_reference/types.d.ts

To use these TypeScript definitions in your project, you can copy types.d.ts to the root of the /html directory, and you can then see and use TypeScript definitions for Premiere Pro's UXP APIs in Visual Studio Code.

Based on my search, here's what I found about the Premiere Pro UXP `createInsertProjectItemAction` method and SequenceEditor for inserting clips to the timeline:

## Overview

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.

## The createInsertProjectItemAction Method

The SequenceEditor provides the `getEditor(sequenceObject: Sequence)` method to get a Sequence Editor reference for editing the sequence timeline. The `createInsertProjectItemAction` method creates an insert ProjectItem into Sequence Action with the following signature:

```javascript
createInsertProjectItemAction(projectItem: ProjectItem, time: TickTime, videoTrackIndex: number, audioTrackIndex: number, limitShift: boolean): Action
```

Note: If you pass a track index greater than the number of existing tracks, a new track will be created.

## Sample Usage

Here's a sample with all of the required parameters: `SequenceEditor.createInsertProjectItemAction(projectItem, TickTime, videoTrackIndex, audioTrackIndex, limitShift)`

## Known Issues

Some developers have been trying to use the new UXP `createInsertProjectItemAction()` method to insert a clip into a sequence's timeline, but encountered the error "Script Action failed to execute."(no content)In some cases, the error happens at the `createInsertProjectItemAction` line, and execution of the script stops before it even gets to the `executeAction()` function.

## API Availability

Adobe announced an update for UXP APIs in the Premiere Pro Beta version. The SequenceEditor APIs were part of this update, which allows for various sequence editing operations.(no content)UXP in Premiere Pro is in beta and very new, so many APIs haven't been built yet.(no content)Users have confirmed issues while running Premiere Pro beta app version 25.3.0 build 33.

## Related Methods

There's also a `createOverwriteItemAction` method: `createOverwriteItemAction(projectItem: ProjectItem, time: TickTime, videoTrackIndex: number, audioTrackIndex: number): Action` which creates an overwrite Sequence with ProjectItem Action.

## Resources

Sample code can be found in a GitHub repository that developers have been sharing in the Adobe community forums.

Based on my search results, I found relevant information about Premiere Pro UXP and the razor tool/split cut functionality. Here's what I discovered:

## Premiere Pro UXP and Razor Tool/Timeline Editing

### UXP API Limitations for Razor Tool

There is not yet any UXP API that mimics the razor tool. This was confirmed in an Adobe Community discussion from October 2025 where a developer was trying to build a Premiere Pro plugin with UXP.

A developer was building a Premiere Pro plugin with UXP and faced challenges trying to mimic the razor tool feature. They wanted to programmatically create cut sections, add markers or tags to indicate which parts came from the original source, place them in a new sequence, export SRT files programmatically, and extract video metadata.

### What UXP Can and Cannot Do

According to the Adobe community response:

- **Cannot do**: There is not yet any UXP API that mimics the razor tool.
- **Limitation**: In PPro, all markers and metadata associated with trackItems are actually attached to the backing projectItem; it's not possible to have different markers and metadata for each trackItem.
- **Can do**: Placing trackItems in a sequence is no problem (same for CEP+ExtendScript and UXP). Export .srt file is also possible - you would use an output preset (.epr file) that specifies whatever settings you want.

### Standard Razor Tool Usage (Non-UXP)

For standard timeline editing in Premiere Pro:

- Select the Razor tool on the panel, then select on the clip where you want to create a split.
- You can type the letter C on your keyboard - that's the Razor tool shortcut in Premiere Pro.
- Move the playhead and press Ctrl + K (Windows) or Cmd + K (Mac) for a quick cut. This splits the selected clip at that point so you can edit each part separately.
- You can hold down the Alt key while using the Razor Tool to split only one track at a time. And if you hold down the Shift key, you can split all tracks simultaneously.

### Undoing Razor Cuts

Right click on the cut in the timeline and from the drop down menu choose "Join Through Edits" to undo a razor cut. Alternatively, just click on the cut and press the delete key. It will not delete the entire clip, just the cut.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP TrackItem setInPoint, setOutPoint, start, end, and modification:

## UXP API for TrackItem In/Out Points

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform).

### Getting Track Item Times

In the UXP API, for track items you can:

- `getStartTime(): Promise<TickTime>` - Returns a TickTime object representing the starting sequence time of this track item relative to the sequence start time. `getEndTime(): Promise<TickTime>` - Returns a TickTime object representing the ending sequence time of this track item relative to the sequence start time.

- `getInPoint(): Promise<TickTime>` - Returns a TickTime object representing the track item in point relative to the start time of the project item referenced by this track item.

- `getOutPoint(): Promise<TickTime>` - Returns a TickTime object representing the track item out point relative to the start time of the project item referenced by this track item.

### Setting Track Item In/Out Points (UXP Actions)

`createSetInPointAction(tickTime: TickTime): Action` - Create SetInPointAction for setting the track item in point relative to the start time of the project item referenced by this track item.(no content)`createSetOutPointAction(tickTime: TickTime): Action` - Create SetOutPointAction for setting the track item out point relative to the start time of the project item referenced by this track item.

### Setting Start/End Times

`createSetStartAction(tickTime: TickTime): Action` - Create set start time action for sequence. `createSetEndAction(tickTime: TickTime): Action` - Create set end time action for sequence.

### Moving Track Items

`createMoveAction(tickTime: TickTime): Action` - Returns an action that moves the inPoint of the track item to a new time, by shifting it by a number of seconds.

## Legacy ExtendScript API

In the older ExtendScript API:

- The `end` property represents the visible end time of the trackItem in the sequence, relative to the beginning of its corresponding sequence. This may differ from the trackItem's out point, which is relative to the source. It's a Time object that is read/write.

- The `start` property represents the visible start time of the trackItem in the sequence, relative to the beginning of its corresponding sequence. This may differ from the trackItem's in point, which is relative to the source. It's a Time object that is read/write.

### Known Limitations

It is possible to GET the inPoint and outPoint of a clip located within a sequence on a video or audio track, and also possible to GET the inPoint and outPoint of the sequence itself, however some users have reported difficulty finding a way to SET the inPoint and outPoint of the sequence in UXP.(no content)ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

content.content: Prompt is too long

# UXP API Updates for Premiere Pro

## New Methods Added

**ClipProjectItem API:**
- `attachProxy()` and `changeMediaPath()` for managing footage

**EncoderManager API:**
- `getExportFileExtension()` for determining file formats based on sequence and preset

**SequenceEditor APIs:**
- `createOverwriteItemAction()`, `createInsertProjectItemAction()`, `createRemoveItemsAction()`, and `createCloneTrackItemAction()` for sequence editing

**TrackItemSelection API:**
- `getTrackItems()` to access items within selections

**ProjectUtils API:**
- `getProjectViewIds()`, `getProjectFromViewId()`, and `GetSelectionFromViewId()` for project navigation

## Timeline & Clip Features

The update includes "creating action that insert, overwrite, or remove trackItem from sequence," indicating basic timeline manipulation capabilities. However, there is no mention of splitting, cutting, or advanced clip editing features beyond insertion and removal operations.

## Bug Fixes

Two fixes were implemented: "exportSequence API will handle case of output file name with no extension" and correction of exr export functionality to generate single images rather than sequences.

# UXP API Updates for Premiere Pro

## New Methods Added

**ClipProjectItem API:**
- `attachProxy()` and `changeMediaPath()` for managing footage

**EncoderManager API:**
- `getExportFileExtension()` for determining file formats based on sequence and preset

**SequenceEditor APIs:**
- `createOverwriteItemAction()`, `createInsertProjectItemAction()`, `createRemoveItemsAction()`, and `createCloneTrackItemAction()` for sequence editing

**TrackItemSelection API:**
- `getTrackItems()` to access items within selections

**ProjectUtils API:**
- `getProjectViewIds()`, `getProjectFromViewId()`, and `GetSelectionFromViewId()` for project navigation

## Timeline & Clip Features

The update includes "creating action that insert, overwrite, or remove trackItem from sequence," indicating basic timeline manipulation capabilities. However, there is no mention of splitting, cutting, or advanced clip editing features beyond insertion and removal operations.

## Bug Fixes

Two fixes were implemented: "exportSequence API will handle case of output file name with no extension" and correction of exr export functionality to generate single images rather than sequences.

# TrackItem Interface Methods & Properties

Based on the TypeScript definitions provided, here's a comprehensive extraction:

## AudioClipTrackItem Methods
- `getMatchName()` - Returns internal matchname
- `getName()` - Returns display name
- `getIsSelected()` - Checks selection status
- `getSpeed()` - Returns speed value
- `isAdjustmentLayer()` - Identifies adjustment layers
- `isSpeedReversed()` - Checks if reversed
- `createMoveAction(tickTime)` - Shifts in-point
- `getInPoint()` - Returns in-point
- `getOutPoint()` - Returns out-point
- `createSetInPointAction(tickTime)`
- `createSetOutPointAction(tickTime)`
- `getStartTime()` - Sequence start time
- `getEndTime()` - Sequence end time
- `createSetStartAction(tickTime)`
- `createSetEndAction(tickTime)`
- `getDuration()`
- `getType()` - Track item type index
- `isDisabled()` - Mute/disable status
- `createSetDisabledAction(disabled)`
- `createSetNameAction(inName)`
- `getMediaType()` - UUID of media type
- `getTrackIndex()`
- `getProjectItem()`
- `getComponentChain()` - Audio component chain

## VideoClipTrackItem Methods
Identical to AudioClipTrackItem, plus:
- `createAddVideoTransitionAction(videoTransition, options)`
- `createRemoveVideoTransitionAction(transitionPosition)`

## SequenceEditor Methods
- `createRemoveItemsAction(trackItemSelection, ripple, mediaType)`
- `createInsertProjectItemAction(projectItem, time, videoTrackIndex, audioTrackIndex)`
- `createOverwriteItemAction(projectItem, time, videoTrackIndex, audioTrackIndex)`
- `createCloneTrackItemAction(trackItem, timeOffset, videoTrackVerticalOffset, audioTrackVerticalOffset, alignToVideo, isInsert)` - Duplicates via insert/overwrite
- `insertMogrtFromPath(path, time, videoTrackIndex, audioTrackIndex)`
- `insertMogrtFromLibrary(libraryName, elementName, time, videoTrackIndex, audioTrackIndex)`

**Note:** No explicit "split" or "cut" methods exist; use removal + positioning actions instead.

Here are the search results for your query about UXP Premiere Pro samples related to split/cut timeline editing:

## Main Resources Found

### AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples Repository
These instructions explain how to develop UXP plugins within Premiere Pro. As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins.(no content)The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.

**Requirements:**
You'll need: Premiere Pro BETA build (available through Creative Cloud Desktop), UXP Developer Tool (also available through Creative Cloud Desktop), and the Adobe third-party sample panel from the premiere-api directory in the Git repository.

### Timeline Editing APIs (from types.d.ts)
The UXP API for Premiere Pro includes several timeline editing functions:

- `getEditor(sequenceObject: Sequence): SequenceEditor` - Get Sequence Editor reference for editing the sequence timeline
- `performSceneEditDetectionOnSelection(clipOperation: string, trackItemSelection: TrackItemSelection): Promise<boolean>` - Performs cut detection on the sequence selection
- `EVENT_SNAP_RAZOR_TO_PLAYHEAD` - Event occurs when the razor tool hovers over the playhead and snaps into position for a cut
- `EVENT_SNAP_RAZOR_TO_MARKER` - Event occurs when the razor tool hovers over all types of markers and snaps into position for a cut

### Current Status
As of Premiere Pro 25.6, CEP extensions to Premiere Pro have been superseded by UXP Extensibility. If you are starting new development, start in UXP. CEP extensions continue to be supported; the plan is to support both CEP and UXP for a calendar year, after which they will remove support for CEP extensibility.

### Limitations
UXP scripting in Premiere Pro is experimental and limited. Some features (like timeline and sequence editing) may not be available yet. For full automation, use the CEP (legacy) panel.

The direct repository link is: **https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples**

Based on my search, here's what I found regarding Premiere Pro UXP's `createCloneTrackItemAction` for duplicating clips:

## createCloneTrackItemAction in Premiere Pro UXP

The `createCloneTrackItemAction` function is defined to duplicate a trackItem using an insert or overwrite edit method to a destination track. It takes parameters including `trackItem` (VideoClipTrackItem or AudioClipTrackItem), `timeOffset` (TickTime), `videoTrackVerticalOffset`, `audioTrackVerticalOffset`, `alignToVideo` (boolean), and `isInsert` (boolean).(no content)The target track and start time of the trackItem is determined using an offset value from the original trackItem position.

## UXP API Status

UXP in Premiere Pro is in beta and very very new, so lots of APIs haven't been built yet. If you need a production panel today or in the near future, you're going to need to build it in CEP.(no content)Adobe recommends letting them know what features you need in UXP to make sure they get added.

## Related API Updates

There have been recent updates to UXP APIs in Premiere Pro Beta, including ClipProjectItem API (which allows for attaching proxy or high resolution footage or replacing footage via attachProxy() and changeMediaPath()), EncoderManager API, and SequenceEditor APIs.

## Traditional Workarounds for Duplicating Clips

For non-UXP workflows, users have asked about fast ways to duplicate items on the timeline, similar to how Photoshop allows selecting a layer and using Alt + Drag to duplicate and place a new object.(no content)One workaround mentioned is making a copy of a clip within the sequence by alt-dragging onto a new layer and then dragging the result back.

If you're looking for specific workarounds involving split operations with the UXP API's `createCloneTrackItemAction`, the search results don't show detailed community discussions about that specific combination. You may want to check the [Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums](https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/) for more specific UXP development questions, as that appears to be the primary forum for Premiere Pro UXP development discussions.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP beta and its API:

## Premiere Pro UXP Beta Overview

On Dec 5th, 2024, Adobe opened their public beta for UXP Plugins in Premiere Pro.(no content)UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications, powered by a modern JavaScript engine that offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.

### Current Status

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.(no content)UXP in Premiere Pro is still in beta at this point, so there are lots of features/functions that either don't exist or don't fully work as needed.

### API Updates and New Methods

Recent updates to the UXP APIs include:

ClipProjectItem API which allows for attach proxy or high resolution footage or replace footage (attachProxy(), changeMediaPath()), EncoderManager API which allows for getting file extension based on input sequence and preset (getExportFileExtension()), and SequenceEditor APIs.(no content)Earlier updates included new APIs like AppPreference (access and control over selected app preference settings), FrameRate (access and control for FrameRate object), ProjectUtils (access over user's ProjectItemSelection in the Project Panel), and ProjectItemSelection.

### Undocumented/Experimental APIs

Regarding hidden or undocumented methods, the search results reveal some interesting points:

In current Premiere Pro builds (2023–2025), certain functions like moveToTrack() appear to exist in the QE object model but are not operational. Calling it returns various signatures like moveToTrack(int), moveToTrack(int, int), moveToTrack(int, int, boolean), and moveToTrack(trackObject, flags) - but none resulted in track movement.(no content)The function in QE appears to be stubbed or deprecated without a documented replacement.(no content)Adobe has stated the QE DOM will remain "100% unsupported, and not at all recommended."

### Technical Architecture

In UXP, a method call is asynchronous and does not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.(no content)Both UXP and Premiere APIs are actively evolving, with new capabilities added in each release.

The search didn't reveal specific documentation about hidden experimental APIs beyond the QE DOM methods, which Adobe explicitly discourages using. For official API exploration, the documentation is available at the [Adobe Developer site](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/).

Based on the search results, here's what I found about using UXP in Premiere Pro to simulate split clip functionality with in/out points:

## UXP Limitations for Clip Splitting in Premiere Pro

"UXP in Premiere Pro is in beta and very very new so lots of APIs haven't been built yet. If you need a production panel today or in the near future, you're going to need to build it in CEP."

### Current UXP Capabilities for In/Out Points

At the moment, it is possible to GET the inPoint and the outPoint of a clip located within a sequence on a video or audio track via `getStartTime(): Promise<TickTime>` and `getEndTime(): Promise<TickTime>`. It is also possible to GET the inPoint and outPoint of the sequence itself: `getInPoint(): Promise` and `getOutPoint(): Promise`. However, there isn't a way to SET the inPoint and outPoint of the sequence.

### Trimming and Splitting Challenges

Developers have figured out how to set clip in/out points, hoping to use them to trim clips, but can't seem to find any actions that might do that. The move action works, but there aren't any trimming actions on a clip, track, or sequence.

### Workarounds and Recommendations

1. **Use CEP instead**: If you need a production panel today or in the near future, you're going to need to build it in CEP, as UXP APIs haven't been fully built yet.

2. **Manual workaround in Premiere Pro**: For split screen workflows using different sections of the same clip, don't copy/paste or duplicate - instead make separate timelines and make sure you take the in and out point from the source clip. Do not open the clip from the timeline into the source monitor.

3. **Standard splitting methods**: If keyboard shortcuts aren't working, try the Razor tool and creating the edit points manually.

### Community Resources

Adobe recommends letting them know what features you need in UXP to make sure they get added. The Creative Cloud Developer Forums appear to be the best place for Premiere Pro UXP discussions.

The UXP API for Premiere Pro is still maturing, and key clip manipulation features like splitting, trimming, and setting sequence in/out points programmatically are not yet fully available.

content.content:
# UXP Clip In/Out Point Technical Details

## Working Methods
- `clipProjectItem.createSetOutPointAction` - Sets out point on source clips before insertion into sequence
- `trackItem.createSetStartAction` and `trackItem.createSetEndAction` - Recommended alternatives for resizing durations

## Broken/Missing Methods
- `trackItem.createSetInPointAction` and `trackItem.createSetOutPointAction` - Currently broken; return empty actions
- No native trim or ripple trim actions exposed in the API

## Adobe's Official Position
According to Cathy Dong (Adobe staff): "Clip in and out point determines the length of trackItem when it is used to be inserted into the sequence." However, once items are in the sequence, these points no longer apply. Adobe acknowledges the issue: "We are going to introduce another API for trimming the trackItem already in sequence soon."

## Workarounds
- Use `trackItem.createSetStartAction` and `trackItem.createSetEndAction` instead of the in/out point methods
- Reference Cathy Dong's solution in the linked thread about ripple delete operations

## Current Status
As of version 25.4.0, these APIs remain problematic despite announced fixes.

content.content:
# UXP Basic Methods in Premiere Pro

## APIs Discussed

The forum post covers three primary APIs for project item management:

1. **Move Items**: `rootItem.createMoveItemAction(movedItem, binItem)` enables relocating project items into specific bins.

2. **Rename Project Items**: Uses `ppro.Metadata.createSetProjectMetadataAction()` combined with XMP API to modify metadata. The process involves retrieving existing metadata with `projectItem.getProjectMetadata()`, then setting the name property via `"http://ns.adobe.com/premierePrivateProjectMetaData/1.0/"`.

3. **Duplicate Sequences**: `sequence.createCloneAction()` creates sequence copies, which can then be renamed using the metadata API mentioned above.

## Timeline Editing Capabilities

**No timeline editing functions are mentioned.** The discussion focuses exclusively on project management operations—moving, renaming, and duplicating sequences at the project level. There are no references to "splitting, cutting, or manipulating clips" within timelines. The post addresses organizational tasks rather than editing operations like trimming, transitions, or effects application.

The related topics suggest broader API limitations, with one thread titled "Migrating from CEP to UXP: Community API Gap & Issue Summary" hinting at potential functionality gaps in current UXP capabilities.

Based on my search, here's what I found about `performSceneEditDetectionOnSelection` in Premiere Pro's UXP API:

## UXP API Method

The method signature in the UXP API is:
`performSceneEditDetectionOnSelection(clipOperation: string, trackItemSelection: TrackItemSelection): Promise<boolean>` - which performs cut detection on the sequence selection.

## ExtendScript API (Legacy)

In the older ExtendScript API, the method is:
`app.project.sequences[index].performSceneEditDetectionOnSelection(actionDesired, applyCutsToLinkedAudio, sensitivity)` - which performs cut detection on the sequence selection and returns a boolean; true if successful.

## Key Differences Between UXP and ExtendScript

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous and does not block the UI thread.

## Common Issues and Solutions

A common issue is that the function doesn't work without proper track item selection. The solution was not to have an active sequence; the solution was to have track items selected. Users found they could get the code to analyze clips successfully by selecting the media on the timeline before running the code. If the sequence is active but none of the media is selected on the timeline, then the analyze clips progress bar never advances.

## Platform Status

UXP is the current extensibility standard for Adobe Creative Cloud applications, supported by a constantly growing set of applications, including Premiere (version 25.6), Photoshop, and InDesign.(no content)As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

The `clipOperation` parameter in the UXP version would typically accept string values like "ApplyCuts" or "CreateMarkers" to specify what action to take when cuts are detected.

Based on my search, here's what I found about the Premiere Pro UXP `performSceneEditDetectionOnSelection` function and its parameters:

## UXP API Definition

The `performSceneEditDetectionOnSelection` function takes two parameters:
- `clipOperation: string` - The operation to perform
- `trackItemSelection: TrackItemSelection` - The track item selection to operate on

It returns a `Promise<boolean>` and performs cut detection on the sequence selection.

### ClipOperation Constants

The available clip operation values are defined as constants:
- `SEQUENCE_OPERATION_APPLYCUT` - corresponds to "ApplyCuts"
- `SEQUENCE_OPERATION_CREATEMARKER` - corresponds to "CreateMarkers"
- `SEQUENCE_OPERATION_CREATESUBCLIP` - corresponds to "CreateSubclips"

## ExtendScript API (Legacy)

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported and planned to remain so through September 2026.

The legacy ExtendScript version has a different signature. The ExtendScript function is called as `app.project.sequences[index].performSceneEditDetectionOnSelection(actionDesired, applyCutsToLinkedAudio, sensitivity)` and performs cut detection on the sequence selection, returning a boolean (true if successful).(no content)The ExtendScript parameters include:
- `action`: 'ApplyCuts' or 'CreateMarkers'
- `shouldApplyCutsToLinkedAudio`: boolean (true/false)
- `sensitivity`: 'LowSensitivity', 'MediumSensitivity', or 'HighSensitivity'

## Important Usage Note

The solution requires having track items selected. Users were "able to get both versions of the code to analyze the clips successfully by selecting the media on the timeline before running the code." If the sequence is active but none of the media is selected on the timeline, the analyze clips progress bar never advances.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP trim action, ripple delete, and API for 2024-2025:

## Current State of Premiere Pro UXP API

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, with plans to remain so through September 2026.(no content)As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins. The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.

## Trim/Ripple Delete API Limitations in UXP

There are significant limitations when it comes to trim and ripple delete functionality in the current UXP API:

Developers have found that while clip in/out points can be set, there don't appear to be any actions that use those points for trimming. The move action works, but developers cannot find any trimming actions on a clip, track, or sequence.(no content)Developers exploring the Premiere Pro DOM API have found it difficult to understand how to trim or ripple delete a part of a sequence.

## Current API Capabilities

The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin shows how to clone and remove track items, which is the recommended starting point for future integrations.(no content)There is currently no API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks. The QE function appears to be stubbed or deprecated without a documented replacement, meaning there is no programmatic way to manipulate clip positions across video tracks while preserving edit timing.

## Known Bugs with Ripple Delete

In version 25.3, a bug was introduced where the "ripple edit to playhead" action deletes markers at the cut point instead of preserving them like before.

## Resources

- **UXP Samples Repository**: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples
- **UXP API Documentation**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- **UXP Developer Forum**: https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105

In summary, trim and ripple delete functionality appears to be limited or not yet available in the current Premiere Pro UXP API, which is still maturing. Developers are actively requesting these timeline editing capabilities.

content.content:
# Trimming and Ripple Delete in Premiere Pro UXP: Technical Details

## Current API Capabilities

**Ripple Delete:**
Adobe staff confirms that `sequenceEditor.createRemoveItemsAction()` enables ripple deletion, with a `ripple` parameter controlling whether the operation performs ripple or non-ripple deletion.

**Trimming:**
According to Adobe developer dan2dublin: "We have not exposed API for trimming a trackItem _yet_." The team acknowledges this as a priority gap in achieving parity between CEP and UXP.

## Available Workarounds

**CEP/ExtendScript Approach (Currently Functional):**
Dan2dublin explains the viable alternative: modify trackItem start or end times by changing them "to a new ticktime." The documentation references include:
- TrackItem.start and TrackItem.end properties
- Sequence.getPlayerPosition() to retrieve CTI position for dynamic trimming points

This mirrors keyboard shortcuts ("q" or "w" for trim-to-playhead functionality).

**Related UXP Methods:**
- `sequenceEditor.createCloneTrackItemAction()`
- `sequenceEditor.createOverwriteItemAction()`

## Adobe's Future Plans

Dan2dublin indicates reaching UXP parity is prioritized but provides no firm timeline. CEP will remain supported "at least another year" following UXP API expansion, though CEP deprecation is underway.

Based on my search results, I found information about the `createRemoveItemsAction` function in Premiere Pro's UXP API.

## `createRemoveItemsAction` in Premiere Pro UXP

The `createRemoveItemsAction` method has the following signature:

```typescript
createRemoveItemsAction(trackItemSelection: TrackItemSelection, ripple: boolean, mediaType: Constants.MediaType, shiftOverLapping?: boolean): Action
```

### Parameters:

1. **trackItemSelection** (`TrackItemSelection`): The selection of track items to remove
2. **ripple** (`boolean`): When set to `true`, this enables ripple delete behavior - subsequent clips will shift to fill the gap left by the removed items
3. **mediaType** (`Constants.MediaType`): Specifies the type of media being removed
4. **shiftOverLapping** (`boolean`, optional): An optional parameter to control overlapping item behavior

This method creates a remove action for a sequence that can be executed to delete track items.

### Context

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications, powered by a modern JavaScript engine that offers programmatic access to many Premiere functions.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin shows how to clone and remove track items, which would be helpful for understanding practical usage of this API.

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

The keyboard shortcut for Cut (Add Edit) in Premiere Pro is **Ctrl + K** on Windows or **Cmd + K** on Mac.(no content)Hitting Ctrl+K (Cmd+K) cuts the clip in two. It's like using the Razor Tool, only faster. This works on active tracks. Add the Shift modifier key, and you cut all clips under the Playhead in two.

### Related Shortcuts:

- **C**: Razor Tool - for manually slicing clips
- On Mac, CMD-K works for individual layers, and SHIFT-CMD-K cuts through all tracks. You can look for "Add Edit to All Tracks" in keyboard shortcuts for cutting across all tracks.
- Ctrl-Shift-K cuts selected tracks only

### How the Add Edit Works:

The way to do this in Premiere Pro is with Cmd+K (Mac) or Ctrl+K (PC). This shortcut will only 'cut' on a clip in an active track. To activate a track see that it is either dark or light grey - if it is light grey it is active, dark is deactive. Select the track name to switch the active/deactive state.

### Customizing Shortcuts:

To create a custom keyboard shortcut, you'll want to go to Premiere Pro > Keyboard Shortcuts or use the hotkey ⌘+Option+K (Mac). This will bring up a keyboard layout containing a cheat sheet of all the hotkeys available in Premiere Pro.(no content)Premiere Pro allows you to customize and remap your keyboard shortcuts through the Keyboard Shortcuts panel (Edit > Keyboard Shortcuts). Personalize your setup to match your unique editing style.

### Regarding Programmatic/Script Access:

The search results don't specifically cover programmatic scripting to execute the Ctrl+K/Add Edit command. For programmatic control of Premiere Pro, you would typically need to use:

1. **Adobe ExtendScript** - Adobe's JavaScript-based scripting language
2. **CEP (Common Extensibility Platform)** panels
3. Third-party automation tools that can send keyboard commands

Based on my search results, here's what I found about executing menu commands and keyboard shortcuts in Premiere Pro via ExtendScript:

## Key Findings

### No Direct Menu Command API in Premiere Pro
The question of executing menu commands from CEP plugins or ExtendScript has been raised in the Adobe community. While Illustrator has `app.executeMenuCommand()` and InDesign has `app.menuActions`, users have been looking for a similar API for Premiere Pro.(no content)Keyboard shortcuts are an option, but they can cause issues in localized environments. API access is much more preferred.

### QE (Quality Engineering) DOM as an Alternative
For certain editing functions, the QE (Quality Engineering) library can provide alternatives. For example, users have found that calling the RAZOR method works for splitting clips. Sample code shows: `app.enableQE();` followed by `var sqe = qe.project.getActiveSequence();` to get the active QE sequence.

### CEP Panel Approach
You cannot directly assign an ExtendScript to a keyboard shortcut in Premiere. However, you can create a CEP HTML extension that can provide UI for your user (in the form of a dockable panel, or a floating window), or it can also have no visible UI.(no content)Once you have the HTML Panel running, you can communicate with Premiere using ExtendScript, which is the actual API to Premiere. ExtendScript is very similar to JavaScript.

### Important Note on ExtendScript's Future
As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

### Resources
The PProPanel sample exercises Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API and can be found at: https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/tree/master/PProPanel.

Unfortunately, there doesn't appear to be a `qe.app.triggerCommand` method or similar direct menu command execution API in Premiere Pro's ExtendScript. For triggering menu-like functionality, developers typically need to use the QE DOM methods for specific functions or work around limitations using CEP panels.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP workarounds for simulating the razor tool and working with clip inPoint/outPoint:

## Key Findings

### No Native UXP Razor Tool API
There is not yet any UXP API that mimics the razor tool. This is a significant limitation for developers building Premiere Pro plugins with UXP who need to programmatically split clips.

### Current UXP In/Out Point Capabilities
At the moment, it is possible to GET the inPoint and the outPoint of a clip located within a sequence on a video or audio track via: getStartTime(): Promise and getEndTime(): Promise. It is also possible to GET the inPoint and outPoint of the sequence itself: getInPoint(): Promise and getOutPoint(): Promise. However, I haven't been able to find a way to SET the inPoint and outPoint of the sequence.

### Clip Trimming Challenges
Developers have figured out how to set clip in/out points, hoping to use them to trim clips, but can't find any actions that might do that. There isn't any way to trim a clip in UXP currently. The move action seems to work, but there are no trimming actions on a clip, track, or sequence.

### ExtendScript API (Legacy)
In ExtendScript, the inPoint is accessible via `app.project.sequences[index].audioTracks[index].clips[index].inPoint` or `app.project.sequences[index].videoTracks[index].clips[index].inPoint`. The in point set on the source for this trackItem instance, relative to the beginning of the source, is a Time object that is read/write.

### Transition Timeline
As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

### Workarounds Mentioned
Placing trackItems in a sequence is no problem, and this is the same for both CEP+ExtendScript and UXP. This suggests that instead of splitting clips with a razor-like function, developers may need to work around by creating new trackItems with adjusted in/out points to simulate the split effect.

### Marker Limitations
In Premiere Pro, all markers and metadata associated with trackItems are actually attached to the backing projectItem; it's not possible to have different markers and metadata for each trackItem.

In summary, there's currently no direct UXP API to simulate the razor tool. The suggested workaround approach would involve cloning/placing clips with adjusted inPoint and outPoint values rather than actually splitting existing clips, though the full trimming capabilities are still limited in UXP.

Based on my search results, I found general information about Premiere Pro UXP APIs, but I did not find specific documentation about an `app.executeCommand` method for menu commands like "Add Edit Cut" in the UXP context. Let me share what I found:

## Search Results Summary

The search did not return specific documentation for `app.executeCommand` with "Add Edit Cut" menu command in Premiere Pro's UXP API. Here's what I found:

### Premiere Pro UXP API Overview

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.(no content)The Premiere DOM can be accessed via UXP. From here, you can open documents, modify them, run menu items, and more.

### Key Differences from ExtendScript

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous. This means they blocked the Premiere UI while they were executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread.

### Regarding executeCommand

From the After Effects context (which may differ from Premiere Pro): You can execute any menu commands with app.findMenuCommandId() and app.executeCommand(). However, note that those functions are not documented, so they are not supported officially.

### "Add Edit" / Cut Command

The keyboard shortcut for "Cut (Add Edit)" is Ctrl + K / Cmd + K. This is the Premiere Pro timeline editing function that adds an edit point (cut) at the playhead position.

### Current UXP Status

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP; Unified Extensibility Platform. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

### Recommendation

The specific `app.executeCommand` method for running menu commands like "Add Edit" does not appear to be explicitly documented in the current UXP API documentation for Premiere Pro. The official documentation at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ would be the best place to check for the most up-to-date API methods available for executing menu commands programmatically in UXP.

From the After Effects context (which may differ from Premiere Pro): You can execute any menu commands with app.findMenuCommandId() and app.executeCommand(). However, note that those functions are not documented, so they are not supported officially.

### "Add Edit" / Cut Command

The keyboard shortcut for "Cut (Add Edit)" is Ctrl + K / Cmd + K. This is the Premiere Pro timeline editing function that adds an edit point (cut) at the playhead position.

### Current UXP Status

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP; Unified Extensibility Platform. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

### Recommendation

The specific `app.executeCommand` method for running menu commands like "Add Edit" does not appear to be explicitly documented in the current UXP API documentation for Premiere Pro. The official documentation at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ would be the best place to check for the most up-to-date API methods available for executing menu commands programmatically in UXP.

# Executing Menu Commands in Premiere Pro Scripts

Based on the forum discussion provided, here are the technical details:

## Available Methods

**No native API exists.** An Adobe Employee explicitly states: "No, there is no such API."

Premiere Pro lacks equivalent functionality to:
- Illustrator's `app.executeMenuCommand()`
- InDesign's `app.menuActions`
- After Effects' similar capabilities

## Workarounds Mentioned

The forum discussion identifies these alternatives:

1. **Keyboard Shortcuts** - Trigger via simulated key presses, though the original poster notes this approach has "many issues on localized environment[s]"

2. **Hardware Integration via CEP Plugin** - The proposed workflow combines:
   - OS-level driver (C++)
   - Adobe CEP Plugin
   - ExtendScript
   - Direct Premiere Pro actions

3. **Control Surface Support** - Mentioned as providing "much more capability" than scripting alone

## Key Limitation

The poster specifically requires "single action without dialog" execution and prefers "API access" over keyboard shortcuts due to localization problems affecting menu command names across different language versions.

**Bottom Line:** Programmers must use workarounds like keyboard simulation or hardware control surfaces, as Premiere Pro's scripting API provides no direct menu command execution method.

content.content:
# ExtendScript Clip Cutting Technical Details

Based on the forum discussion provided, here are the key technical insights:

## Core Problem
The user sought to automate cutting video clips in Premiere Pro at specific timestamps using ExtendScript, but encountered issues with a non-existent `split()` method and timecode-to-ticks conversion.

## Solution Approach
**Adobe Expert Bruce Bullis provided this guidance:**

> "There is no split method. You could truncate (change the end point) of the earlier trackItem, and insert a new trackItem"

Instead of a single split operation, the proper approach involves:
1. Truncating an existing track item to establish the cut point
2. Creating a new track item (based on the same project item) positioned after the truncated segment

## Timecode Conversion
For timestamp calculations, Bullis referenced using a `Time()` object rather than manual conversion:

> "A Time() object will perform the conversion for you; see PProPanel. There are 254016000000 ticks/second."

## Key Resources
The expert directed developers to the **PProPanel sample code** on Adobe's GitHub repository as the best source for practical implementation examples.

## Technical Stack Requirements
- ES2-compliant ExtendScript (no modern JavaScript features)
- Official Premiere Pro API only
- Proper understanding of trackItem manipulation rather than a nonexistent split method

Based on my search, here's what I found regarding Premiere Pro's UXP future roadmap and timeline editing API support:

## UXP Status in Premiere Pro

The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6! This release represents a major step forward in modernizing Adobe's extensibility ecosystem.(no content)UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level. With UXP, you can build unique tools that integrate with and optimize the most precise, demanding workflows.

## Timeline Editing API - Razor Tool and Split Functionality

There is not yet any UXP API that mimics the razor tool. This is a significant limitation for developers wanting to programmatically split clips.

There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks. Premiere Pro no longer includes a keyboard mappable command like Move Clip Up/Down Between Tracks, meaning even UI automation cannot rely on this.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin, the right starting point for any future integrations, shows how to clone and remove track items.

## Future Roadmap and Developer Input

This general release is just the beginning for UXP in Premiere. Adobe would love developer input to help prioritize what comes next. The Creative Cloud Developer Forums remain the best place to ask questions, help fellow developers, and — most importantly — tell them what you need. Developers are encouraged to share use cases, feedback, and feature requests on the forums. This input directly influences Adobe's roadmap and helps shape the platform.

## ExtendScript Transition Timeline

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.(no content)No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled.

## Key Technical Differences

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, blocking the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

## Summary

Currently, razor/split functionality is **not available** in the UXP API for Premiere Pro. Adobe is actively seeking developer feedback through the Creative Cloud Developer Forums to prioritize new features. The best approach for developers needing timeline editing capabilities is to participate in Adobe's forums and office hours to advocate for these features.

content.text:
Based on my exhaustive research, here is a comprehensive summary of all findings regarding directly editing/cutting/splitting/razor clips on the Premiere Pro timeline using UXP.

---

## EXHAUSTIVE RESEARCH FINDINGS: Premiere Pro UXP Timeline Editing (Cut/Split/Razor)

### 1. OFFICIAL CONFIRMATION: No UXP Razor/Split API Exists

**Adobe has explicitly confirmed**: "There is not yet any UXP API that mimics the razor tool."
- Source: [Adobe Community - UXP Razor Tool Discussion](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/uxp-razor-tool-and-marking-clipped-sections/td-p/15547922)

---

### 2. SequenceEditor Class - Complete Method List

The SequenceEditor class provides these methods (none create cuts/splits):

| Method | Purpose | Can Split? |
|--------|---------|------------|
| `createInsertProjectItemAction(projectItem, time, videoTrackIndex, audioTrackIndex, limitShift)` | Insert clip into sequence | No |
| `createOverwriteItemAction(projectItem, time, videoTrackIndex, audioTrackIndex)` | Overwrite with clip | No |
| `createRemoveItemsAction(trackItemSelection, ripple, mediaType, shiftOverLapping?)` | Remove/ripple delete items | No |
| `createCloneTrackItemAction(trackItem, timeOffset, videoTrackVerticalOffset, audioTrackVerticalOffset, alignToVideo, isInsert)` | Duplicate existing clip | **Potential workaround** |
| `insertMogrtFromPath(...)` | Insert Motion Graphics template | No |
| `insertMogrtFromLibrary(...)` | Insert mogrt from library | No |
| `getLocalMogrtPath()` | Get mogrt directory | No |

Source: [SequenceEditor Documentation](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/sequenceeditor/), [types.d.ts on GitHub](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro/blob/main/src/pages/ppro_reference/types.d.ts)

---

### 3. TrackItem Manipulation Methods

**VideoClipTrackItem / AudioClipTrackItem methods:**

| Method | Purpose | Enables Split? |
|--------|---------|----------------|
| `getInPoint()` / `getOutPoint()` | Get source in/out points | Read only |
| `getStartTime()` / `getEndTime()` | Get sequence position | Read only |
| `createSetInPointAction(tickTime)` | Set source in point | **BROKEN** - returns empty actions |
| `createSetOutPointAction(tickTime)` | Set source out point | **BROKEN** - returns empty actions |
| `createSetStartAction(tickTime)` | Set sequence start time | **Works** - can resize |
| `createSetEndAction(tickTime)` | Set sequence end time | **Works** - can resize |
| `createMoveAction(tickTime)` | Move clip position | Works |
| `createSetDisabledAction(disabled)` | Enable/disable clip | No |
| `createSetNameAction(inName)` | Rename clip | No |
| `getProjectItem()` | Get source project item | No |

**Critical Finding**: `createSetInPointAction` and `createSetOutPointAction` are currently broken per Adobe staff.

Source: [Clip In/Out point usage in UXP](https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/clip-in-out-point-usage-in-uxp-ripple-trim/10800)

---

### 4. performSceneEditDetectionOnSelection - Potential Cut Method

```typescript
performSceneEditDetectionOnSelection(clipOperation: string, trackItemSelection: TrackItemSelection): Promise<boolean>
```

**ClipOperation constants:**
- `SEQUENCE_OPERATION_APPLYCUT` - "ApplyCuts"
- `SEQUENCE_OPERATION_CREATEMARKER` - "CreateMarkers"  
- `SEQUENCE_OPERATION_CREATESUBCLIP` - "CreateSubclips"

**Limitation**: This performs AI-based scene edit detection on selected clips - it does NOT allow arbitrary cut placement. It only detects existing scene changes and applies cuts there.

Source: [types.d.ts](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro/blob/main/src/pages/ppro_reference/types.d.ts)

---

### 5. Razor Events (Not Methods)

The API includes these **event constants** (for listening, not executing):
- `EVENT_SNAP_RAZOR_TO_PLAYHEAD` - Fired when razor tool snaps to playhead
- `EVENT_SNAP_RAZOR_TO_MARKER` - Fired when razor tool snaps to markers

These are **read-only events** - you cannot trigger razor cuts through them.

---

### 6. Potential Workaround: Clone + Adjust Endpoints

**Theoretical approach to simulate a split:**

1. Use `createCloneTrackItemAction()` to duplicate the clip
2. On original clip: use `createSetEndAction()` to trim to cut point
3. On cloned clip: use `createSetStartAction()` to start at cut point
4. Position cloned clip using `createMoveAction()`

**Problems with this approach:**
- `createSetInPointAction` and `createSetOutPointAction` are broken
- `createSetStartAction` and `createSetEndAction` work but change sequence position, not source trim
- No way to properly adjust source in/out points on cloned clip
- Would leave gaps or overlaps

Source: [Trim/Ripple Delete Forum](https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/how-do-i-trim-ripple-delete-a-part-of-a-sequence/10426)

---

### 7. Adobe Staff Statements on Trimming API

Adobe developer **dan2dublin** stated:
> "We have not exposed API for trimming a trackItem _yet_."

Adobe acknowledged this as a priority gap for achieving CEP/UXP parity.

**Workaround suggested by Adobe**: Use `createSetStartAction` and `createSetEndAction` instead of in/out point methods.

Source: [Clip In/Out point usage in UXP](https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/clip-in-out-point-usage-in-uxp-ripple-trim/10800)

---

### 8. No Menu Command Execution API

Unlike After Effects (`app.executeCommand`) or Illustrator (`app.executeMenuCommand`), Premiere Pro has **no API to execute menu commands** like "Add Edit" (Ctrl+K).

Adobe employee confirmed: "No, there is no such API."

Source: [Execute Menu Command Discussion](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/q-execute-menu-command-from-script-cep-extendscript/td-p/9853026)

---

### 9. ExtendScript QE DOM (Legacy - Deprecated)

The **only working programmatic razor method** exists in the **unsupported QE DOM** (ExtendScript):

```javascript
app.enableQE();
var sqe = qe.project.getActiveSequence();
var playerTime = sqe.CTI.timecode; // Format: "00:00:03:38"

// Razor single track
sqe.getVideoTrackAt(0).razor(playerTime);

// Razor all tracks  
sqe.razor(playerTime);
```

**Status**: 
- Works in ExtendScript/CEP
- **NOT available in UXP**
- ExtendScript supported until September 2026
- No additional QE DOM improvements planned

Source: [Perform a cut from script](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/perform-a-cut-from-script/td-p/11389974), [pymiere documentation](https://github.com/qmasingarbe/pymiere/blob/master/example_and_documentation.md)

---

### 10. GitHub Issues & Feature Requests

**Active community requests for timeline editing APIs:**
- [Request for Timeline Editing API Support](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-ideas/request-for-timeline-editing-api-support-clip-track-movement-flattening/idc-p/15625115)
- Multiple forum posts requesting razor/split functionality

**Adobe's response**: They encourage developers to submit feature requests via Creative Cloud Developer Forums to influence the roadmap.

---

### 11. Future Roadmap

From December 2025 Adobe blog post:
> "This general release is just the beginning for UXP in Premiere. We would love your input to help prioritize what comes next."

**No specific timeline** for razor/split API has been announced.

Source: [UXP Arrives in Premiere Blog Post](https://blog.developer.adobe.com/en/publish/2025/12/uxp-arrives-in-premiere-a-new-era-for-plugin-development)

---

## SUMMARY TABLE: All Potential Approaches

| Approach | Available in UXP? | Works? | Notes |
|----------|-------------------|--------|-------|
| Direct razor/split API | No | N/A | Does not exist |
| Clone + adjust in/out points | Partial | **No** | In/out point actions broken |
| Clone + adjust start/end times | Yes | **Partial** | Changes position, not trim points |
| Scene edit detection with ApplyCuts | Yes | **Limited** | Only detects existing scene changes |
| Menu command execution | No | N/A | No API exists |
| QE DOM razor() method | ExtendScript only | Yes | Not available in UXP |
| Keyboard shortcut simulation | No | N/A | No API in UXP |

---

## CONCLUSION

**There is currently NO way to directly cut/split/razor clips on the Premiere Pro timeline using UXP.**

**Best current options:**
1. Use ExtendScript/CEP with QE DOM `razor()` method (supported until Sept 2026)
2. Wait for Adobe to add trimming/split APIs to UXP
3. Submit feature requests to [Creative Cloud Developer Forums](https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105)

**Key Sources:**
- [Adobe UXP API Documentation](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/)
- [SequenceEditor Class](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/sequenceeditor/)
- [types.d.ts TypeScript Definitions](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro/blob/main/src/pages/ppro_reference/types.d.ts)
- [UXP Samples Repository](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples)
- [Creative Cloud Developer Forums](https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105)
